thread.title: ‘You’re not coming in that dress' Hairdresser in drag REFUSED entry to pub
thread.title_full: ‘You’re not coming in that dress' Hairdresser in drag REFUSED entry to pub

title: ‘You’re not coming in that dress' Hairdresser in drag REFUSED entry to pub
text:
MEN SASSY: Mr Murphy has confidence in his chic style 
Adam Murphy, 24, from Manchester, said the Slug and Lettuce pub bouncer left him red-faced when the man claimed there was a policy stating that "men wearing dresses" weren't allowed inside. 
The 24-year-old and his friend Thomas Robinson – who was wearing silver shiny trousers to match - hit a different pub who had no problem with his chic style. 
The glamorous duo had gone to town on getting their gear right for their night out as they had been to open auditions for the new series of Channel Five reality show Big Brother. 
A Slug and Lettuce spokeswoman revealed there is no such policy and the doorman is "no longer employed at that venue". 
MEN STYLISH: The 24-year-old puts a lot of effort into getting his gear right “You’re not coming in in that dress” Doorman 
Mr Murphy told the MEN: "The doorman stopped me and my friend and said 'you’re not coming in in that dress'. 
"I was like, 'are you being serious?' He said yes and when I asked why, he told me that it was policy that men cannot come into the pub in a dress." 
Mr Murphy was told the manager was "too busy" to see him. 
They had rocked up at the pub chain on Deansgate, in Manchester, at around 7pm for their Saturday night out. 
Mr Murphy has confidence in his daring dress sense and wears high heels to work everyday. 
He added: “When it was clear he wasn’t going to let us in at the Slug and Lettuce, we left there and went just along Deansgate to The Living Room, where they were fine with what I was wearing. 
“I wasn’t dressed like a tramp, I wasn’t that extreme, and I wasn’t in a joke outfit - on a weekend and nights out in Manchester this is how I would normally dress.” 
MEN CLASS: The pair had been at auditions for the new series of Big Brother 
The pub chain offered the reveller a bottle of prosecco on his next visit. 
A spokeswoman said: “The management team were not aware of Mr Murphy’s entry refusal until after the event. 
"This does not reflect our company policy and the doorman in question is no longer employed at the venue. We have apologised personally for any offence caused.” Related articles
